title: Isaiah Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Isaiah chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Isaiah Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Isaiah Chapter 2.

questions.question: Who is the author of the word concerning Judah and Jerusalem in Isaiah 2?
questions.correctAnswer: Isaiah the son of Amoz
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:1 states that the word concerning Judah and Jerusalem was seen by Isaiah the son of Amoz.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 2:2, what will be established in the last days?
options: The mountain of the LORD's house
questions.correctAnswer: The mountain of the LORD's house
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:2 says that the mountain of the LORD's house shall be established in the top of the mountains in the last days.

questions.question: Where shall all nations flow unto, according to Isaiah 2:2?
options: The mountain of the LORD's house
questions.correctAnswer: The mountain of the LORD's house
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:2 states that all nations shall flow unto the mountain of the LORD's house.

questions.question: What will go forth out of Zion, according to Isaiah 2:3?
options: The law and the word of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: The law and the word of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:3 mentions that out of Zion shall go forth the law and the word of the LORD.

questions.question: What will people do with their swords and spears in Isaiah 2?
options: Beat them into plowshares and pruninghooks
questions.correctAnswer: Beat them into plowshares and pruninghooks
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:4 says they shall beat their swords into plowshares and their spears into pruninghooks.

questions.question: What is the invitation given to the house of Jacob in Isaiah 2:5?
options: Come and walk in the light of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Come and walk in the light of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:5 invites the house of Jacob to walk in the light of the LORD.

questions.question: Why has the house of Jacob been forsaken, according to Isaiah 2:6?
options: Because they are soothsayers like the Philistines
Because they worship the LORD only
questions.correctAnswer: Because they are soothsayers like the Philistines
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:6 explains that the house of Jacob was forsaken because they were soothsayers like the Philistines.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 2:7 say fills the land of Jacob?
questions.correctAnswer: Silver, gold, horses, and chariots
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:7 states that their land is full of silver, gold, horses, and chariots, and there is no end to their treasures.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 2:8, what do the people worship?
options: The work of their own hands
questions.correctAnswer: The work of their own hands
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:8 says their land is full of idols and they worship the work of their own hands.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 2:10 encourages people to enter into the rock and hide in the dust for fear of the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:10 commands to enter into the rock and hide in the dust for fear of the LORD and the glory of his majesty.

questions.question: Who shall be exalted in that day, according to Isaiah 2:11?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD alone
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:11 mentions that the LORD alone shall be exalted in that day.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 2:12 says the day of the LORD will be upon the humble and meek.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:12 says the day of the LORD will be upon every one that is proud and lofty, not the humble and meek.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT mentioned as being brought low in Isaiah 2:13-15?
questions.correctAnswer: The city of Babylon
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:13-15 mentions cedars, oaks, high mountains, hills, towers, and fenced walls, but not the city of Babylon.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Isaiah 2:20: 'In that day a man shall cast his idols of silver, and his idols of gold, which they made each one for himself to worship, to the ______ and to the bats.'
questions.correctAnswer: moles
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:20 says idols will be cast to the moles and to the bats.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 2:22 says to cease from man because his breath is in his nostrils.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:22 instructs to cease from man, for his breath is in his nostrils.

medium.title: Isaiah Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Isaiah Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 2:2-4 teach us about trusting God's plan for peace among nations?
options: By showing that God's house will be exalted and all nations shall flow to it for instruction
By encouraging nations to build more weapons for defense
By advocating for political alliances to achieve peace
By suggesting that peace comes from economic power
questions.correctAnswer: By showing that God's house will be exalted and all nations shall flow to it for instruction
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:2-4 describes the mountain of the LORD’s house being exalted and all nations flowing to it to learn God's ways, leading to beating swords into plowshares and no more war. This teaches us to trust God's plan for peace rather than human efforts like war or politics.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with pride and arrogance. According to Isaiah 2:11-12, what should you remind them about humility?
options: The lofty looks of man shall be humbled and the LORD alone exalted
Pride is a sign of God’s favor and should be embraced
Humility is only necessary for the poor
Humility comes from self-help and human effort
questions.correctAnswer: The lofty looks of man shall be humbled and the LORD alone exalted
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:11-12 teaches that human pride and lofty attitudes will be brought low, and God alone will be exalted. This calls believers to humility and trusting God’s sovereign exaltation rather than self-exaltation.

questions.question: What practical lesson about obedience can be drawn from Isaiah 2:5 when it says, 'O house of Jacob, come ye, and let us walk in the light of the LORD'?
options: Walking in God's light means living obediently and following His ways
Walking in the light means ignoring God’s commands
Walking in the light is only for priests and leaders
Walking in the light means following cultural traditions
questions.correctAnswer: Walking in God's light means living obediently and following His ways
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:5 invites the house of Jacob to walk in the LORD’s light, which implies obedience to God’s revealed truth and living according to His ways. This exemplifies practical Christian living through obedience and devotion.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 2:6-8, what warning is given about material wealth and idolatry, and how does it relate to stewardship?
options: Having wealth and idols leads to forsaking God and trusting in created things
Wealth guarantees God’s blessing and favor
Idols are acceptable if they represent cultural values
Material wealth should be hoarded secretly
questions.correctAnswer: Having wealth and idols leads to forsaking God and trusting in created things
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:6-8 describes how the people’s land is full of silver, gold, horses, and idols, and they worship the work of their own hands. This warns believers against trusting in wealth or idols rather than God, encouraging faithful stewardship and reliance on Him alone.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 2:4 inspire believers to pursue peace and reconciliation in their relationships?
options: By showing that nations will beat swords into plowshares and no longer learn war
By encouraging believers to prepare weapons for conflict
questions.correctAnswer: By showing that nations will beat swords into plowshares and no longer learn war
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:4 depicts a future where God judges among nations, leading to transformation of weapons into farming tools and cessation of war. This encourages believers to seek peace and reconciliation as a reflection of God’s kingdom.

questions.question: A believer is feeling overwhelmed by fear of the LORD’s majesty. According to Isaiah 2:10 and 2:19, what practical advice can be shared?
options: Enter into the rock and hide in the dust as a sign of reverent fear and humility
Ignore the fear and continue in pride
questions.correctAnswer: Enter into the rock and hide in the dust as a sign of reverent fear and humility
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:10 and 2:19 advise hiding in the rock and caves out of fear of the LORD’s majesty, symbolizing reverent humility before God’s power. This teaches believers to respond to God’s holiness with respect and humility rather than fear that leads to pride or denial.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 2:22 teaches that man’s breath in his nostrils should be the ultimate source of our trust and confidence.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:22 instructs to cease trusting in man, whose breath is in his nostrils, because man is limited and cannot be ultimately relied upon. Trust should be placed in God alone.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 2:18-20 show the importance of rejecting idolatry in Christian living?
options: Idols will be utterly abolished and cast away because they cannot save
Idols are to be worshiped alongside God
Idols should be kept as family heirlooms
questions.correctAnswer: Idols will be utterly abolished and cast away because they cannot save
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:18-20 describes idols being abolished and cast to the creatures of the earth, symbolizing that idolatry has no place in true worship. Christians are called to wholly reject idols and trust in God only.

questions.question: A believer struggles to forgive others who have wronged them. How does Isaiah 2:9 inform our understanding of forgiveness and humility?
options: Both the mean and great will bow down, so forgiveness should be extended, but pride must be abandoned
Forgiveness is unnecessary if the offender is proud
Only the great need to forgive
questions.correctAnswer: Both the mean and great will bow down, so forgiveness should be extended, but pride must be abandoned
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:9 notes that both lowly and great will bow down, implying humility is essential. While the verse says 'forgive them not' in context of judgment, the broader teaching emphasizes humility rather than pride, encouraging believers to forgive and walk humbly.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Isaiah 2:3, many people shall go to the mountain of the LORD to learn His ways and walk in His ______.
questions.correctAnswer: paths
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:3 says people will go to the LORD's mountain to be taught His ways and walk in His paths, emphasizing obedience and spiritual discipline.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 2:7 describe the danger of relying on earthly treasures instead of God?
options: The land is full of silver, gold, horses, and chariots, showing trust in material wealth rather than God
Wealth should never be used for God’s purposes
Silver and gold are to be worshiped
questions.correctAnswer: The land is full of silver, gold, horses, and chariots, showing trust in material wealth rather than God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:7 highlights the abundance of material wealth and military resources, warning against placing trust in these rather than in God’s provision and care.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 2:16, what does the mention of 'ships of Tarshish and pleasant pictures' symbolize in the context of pride and trust?
options: They represent human achievements that will be humbled before God
They are eternal sources of security
They are to be worshiped as gods
questions.correctAnswer: They represent human achievements that will be humbled before God
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:16 lists ships and pleasant pictures as symbols of human pride and accomplishments that will be humbled and judged by God, teaching humility and reliance on Him.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 2:1 shows that Isaiah’s prophecy applies specifically to Judah and Jerusalem, indicating the importance of focusing on one’s own spiritual community.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:1 states the word concerning Judah and Jerusalem, highlighting the importance of spiritual devotion and obedience within one's own community and family of faith.

questions.question: How does Isaiah 2:13-15 teach about the futility of human pride in structures and power?
options: All high cedars, oaks, mountains, towers, and walls will be humbled, showing pride in power is futile
Building tall towers ensures safety and blessing
Pride in natural and manmade things brings God’s favor
The highest towers will protect from all harm
questions.correctAnswer: All high cedars, oaks, mountains, towers, and walls will be humbled, showing pride in power is futile
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:13-15 lists lofty natural and manmade things that will be humbled by God’s judgment, teaching believers that pride in power and status is futile and humility before God is essential.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 2:21 teach about the appropriate response to God's majesty during troubling times?
options: Seek refuge in the clefts and tops of rocks in reverent fear of the LORD
Ignore God’s majesty and continue worldly pursuits
questions.correctAnswer: Seek refuge in the clefts and tops of rocks in reverent fear of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:21 encourages people to seek refuge in natural shelters as a symbol of humble reverence and fear of God’s majesty when He shakes the earth, teaching reliance on God in trials.

hard.title: Isaiah Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Isaiah Chapter 2.

questions.question: In Isaiah 2:2, what is prophesied to happen to the mountain of the LORD's house in the last days?
options: It shall be established on the top of the mountains and exalted above the hills
It shall be destroyed by the nations
It shall be hidden under the earth
It shall be moved to a valley
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be established on the top of the mountains and exalted above the hills
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:2 states that the mountain of the LORD's house shall be established on the top of the mountains and exalted above the hills, symbolizing the supreme authority of God's kingdom.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 2:3, what will go forth from Zion and Jerusalem?
options: The law and the word of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: The law and the word of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:3 proclaims that from Zion shall go forth the law, and the word of the LORD from Jerusalem, foreshadowing the teaching role Jerusalem will have among the nations.

questions.question: What transformation of weapons is described in Isaiah 2:4 as part of the peace among nations?
options: Swords beaten into plowshares and spears into pruninghooks
questions.correctAnswer: Swords beaten into plowshares and spears into pruninghooks
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:4 uses a powerful metaphor of turning instruments of war into tools for agriculture, indicating the cessation of war and the advent of peace.

questions.question: Isaiah 2:5 calls the house of Jacob to walk in what?
questions.correctAnswer: The light of the LORD
questions.explanation: The verse invites the people of Jacob to live in accordance with God's guidance, symbolized by walking in His light.

questions.question: What reason does Isaiah give in 2:6 for the LORD forsaking the house of Jacob?
options: Because they are filled with soothsayers and please themselves in the children of strangers
Because they have built many altars
Because they have refused to fight
questions.correctAnswer: Because they are filled with soothsayers and please themselves in the children of strangers
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:6 explains the forsaking as a consequence of the people's engagement with soothsayers like the Philistines and their idolatrous alliances with foreigners.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 2:8 say about the idols in the land?
options: They worship the work of their own hands, that which their own fingers have made
They are made of gold only
They are symbols of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: They worship the work of their own hands, that which their own fingers have made
questions.explanation: This verse critiques idolatry by emphasizing that idols are man-made and worshiping human creations rather than God.

questions.question: Isaiah 2:9 mentions both 'mean man' and 'great man.' What is said about their response?
options: The mean man boweth down, and the great man humbleth himself; therefore forgive them not
questions.correctAnswer: The mean man boweth down, and the great man humbleth himself; therefore forgive them not
questions.explanation: This verse uses parallelism to show that all people, regardless of status, will bow down, but judgment remains due to their sins.

questions.question: In Isaiah 2:10, what are people instructed to do for fear of the LORD and His majesty?
options: Enter into the rock and hide in the dust
Build a tower to the heavens
questions.correctAnswer: Enter into the rock and hide in the dust
questions.explanation: The imagery of hiding in rock and dust illustrates the terror and reverence before God's majesty described in this verse.

questions.question: Which natural features are mentioned in Isaiah 2:13-14 as being humbled by the LORD?
options: Cedars of Lebanon, oaks of Bashan, high mountains, and hills
Rivers of Egypt and plains of Moab
Deserts of Arabia and valleys of Edom
questions.correctAnswer: Cedars of Lebanon, oaks of Bashan, high mountains, and hills
questions.explanation: These verses employ parallelism listing majestic natural features symbolizing pride that will be humbled by God's judgment.

questions.question: What is the fate of idols according to Isaiah 2:18-20?
options: They shall be utterly abolished and cast to moles and bats
They shall be hidden in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be utterly abolished and cast to moles and bats
questions.explanation: These verses emphasize the complete destruction and humiliation of idols as a demonstration of God's supreme power.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 2:22, why should people cease depending on man?
options: Because his breath is in his nostrils and he is mortal
Because man is stronger than God
questions.correctAnswer: Because his breath is in his nostrils and he is mortal
questions.explanation: The verse highlights human frailty contrasted with God's eternal nature, urging reliance on God rather than on mortal man.

questions.question: True or False: Isaiah 2:4 prophesies a time when nations will still learn war.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:4 clearly states that nation shall not lift up sword against nation, neither shall they learn war anymore, indicating the end of war.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominent in Isaiah 2:11 and 2:17 when describing the humility of man and exaltation of the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: Both verses use parallelism by repeating similar phrases about the humbling of man and the exaltation of the LORD to emphasize the theme.

questions.question: How does the imagery of ‘beating swords into plowshares’ in Isaiah 2:4 foreshadow New Testament teachings?
options: It prefigures the peaceable kingdom and the teachings of Jesus about peace
It predicts the destruction of Jerusalem by Rome
It refers to agricultural laws in Leviticus
questions.correctAnswer: It prefigures the peaceable kingdom and the teachings of Jesus about peace
questions.explanation: This imagery anticipates the Messianic peace described in the New Testament, such as in the Sermon on the Mount where Jesus teaches peace and reconciliation.

questions.question: What historical context might explain the presence of soothsayers and idols in Judah as mentioned in Isaiah 2:6-8?
options: Influence of neighboring pagan cultures like the Philistines
Strict monotheism enforced by the king
Complete destruction of idols by the prophets
questions.correctAnswer: Influence of neighboring pagan cultures like the Philistines
questions.explanation: The verses reflect the syncretism and idolatry in Judah due to cultural and political influence from surrounding peoples like the Philistines during Isaiah's time.

theological.title: Isaiah Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Isaiah Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 2:2, what will happen to the mountain of the LORD's house in the last days?
options: It shall be established on top of the mountains and exalted above the hills
It shall be destroyed by fire
It shall be hidden from all nations
It shall be moved to another location
questions.correctAnswer: It shall be established on top of the mountains and exalted above the hills
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:2 states that in the last days, the mountain of the LORD's house shall be established at the top of the mountains and exalted above the hills. This signifies God's supreme authority and the exaltation of His kingdom, consistent with Psalm 99:2 and Revelation 21:10 where God's throne is exalted, and Daniel 2:35 that depicts God’s kingdom as eternal and supreme.

questions.question: What will all nations do in relation to the mountain of the LORD according to Isaiah 2:2?
options: All nations shall flow unto it
All nations shall wage war against it
All nations shall build temples beside it
questions.correctAnswer: All nations shall flow unto it
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:2 describes how all nations will flow unto the mountain of the LORD's house, indicating the universal recognition of God's reign, which echoes the prophetic vision of God's kingdom drawing all peoples as in Zechariah 8:22 and Revelation 7:9.

questions.question: In Isaiah 2:3, what is said to go forth from Zion and Jerusalem?
options: The law and the word of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: The law and the word of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:3 states that out of Zion shall go forth the law and the word of the LORD from Jerusalem, signifying God's rule and instruction going forth to guide the nations. This is consistent with Psalm 147:19, John 1:14 where the Word became flesh, and Hebrews 4:12 which speaks of the living word of God.

questions.question: What transformation of weapons is described in Isaiah 2:4 as a sign of peace?
options: Swords into plowshares and spears into pruninghooks
Swords into bows and arrows into shields
Spears into swords and plowshares into shields
Shields into chariots and swords into horses
questions.correctAnswer: Swords into plowshares and spears into pruninghooks
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:4 prophesies a time when weapons of war will be transformed into tools of agriculture, symbolizing the end of conflict and the establishment of peace. This is a messianic vision affirmed in Micah 4:3 and echoed in the New Testament concept of peace in Romans 14:17 and Ephesians 2:14.

questions.question: What invitation is extended to the house of Jacob in Isaiah 2:5?
options: Come, let us walk in the light of the LORD
Prepare for war against the nations
Build high towers and fortified walls
Worship idols made by their own hands
questions.correctAnswer: Come, let us walk in the light of the LORD
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:5 invites the house of Jacob to walk in the light of the LORD, signifying living in obedience and fellowship with God. This echoes the call to holiness in Leviticus 20:26, the prayer for guidance in Psalm 27:1, and the teaching of walking in the light in 1 John 1:7.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 2:6, why has God forsaken the house of Jacob?
options: Because they were filled with soothsayers and pleased themselves in the children of strangers
Because they trusted only in horses and chariots
Because they refused to worship idols
questions.correctAnswer: Because they were filled with soothsayers and pleased themselves in the children of strangers
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:6 explains God's forsaking of Israel due to their reliance on diviners and foreign alliances, indicating unfaithfulness. This is consistent with warnings against soothsaying in Deuteronomy 18:10-12 and God's judgment for idolatry in Jeremiah 5:30-31.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 2:8 say the people worship that is made by their own hands?
questions.correctAnswer: Idols
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:8 condemns the worship of idols made by human hands, a violation of the first commandment, reaffirmed in Exodus 20:4-5 and Psalm 115:4-8. This also points to the futility of idolatry addressed in 1 Corinthians 10:14.

questions.question: What attitude towards pride and lofty looks does Isaiah 2:11 emphasize?
options: The lofty looks of man shall be humbled and the haughtiness of men bowed down
The lofty looks of man shall be exalted forever
Pride is encouraged as a sign of strength
questions.correctAnswer: The lofty looks of man shall be humbled and the haughtiness of men bowed down
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:11 emphasizes that human pride and arrogance will be humbled before God alone is exalted, consistent with Proverbs 16:18, James 4:6, and 1 Peter 5:5 which warn against pride and affirm God's exaltation.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 2:12, upon whom will the day of the LORD of hosts come?
options: Upon everyone that is proud and lofty
Only upon the meek and humble
questions.correctAnswer: Upon everyone that is proud and lofty
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:12 states that the day of the LORD will come upon the proud and lofty, indicating divine judgment against arrogance. This theme is repeated in Obadiah 1:3-4, Luke 1:52, and 1 Corinthians 1:27.

questions.question: What will happen to idols according to Isaiah 2:18?
options: They shall be worshipped by all
They shall multiply in the land
They shall be hidden away in caves
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be utterly abolished
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:18 proclaims the complete abolition of idols, affirming the exclusive worship of God. This corresponds with Deuteronomy 7:5, Psalm 97:7, and 1 John 5:21 which warn against idolatry and affirm God's uniqueness.

questions.question: In Isaiah 2:19, where will people go for fear of the LORD's majesty?
options: Into the holes of the rocks and caves of the earth
To the mountain of the LORD
To the cities of their enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Into the holes of the rocks and caves of the earth
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:19 describes people hiding in caves and rocks out of fear of the LORD's majesty, illustrating reverence and terror before His judgment. Similar imagery is found in Revelation 6:15-17 and Nahum 1:5-6.

questions.question: What will a man do with his idols of silver and gold on that day according to Isaiah 2:20?
options: Cast them to the moles and bats
questions.correctAnswer: Cast them to the moles and bats
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:20 describes the futility of idols as they will be discarded to creatures like moles and bats, symbolizing complete rejection. This is consistent with Psalm 115:8 and Jeremiah 10:5 which depict idols as worthless and contemptible.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 2:22 exhort men to do regarding trusting in man?
options: Cease from man, for his breath is in his nostrils
Follow the counsel of the proud
questions.correctAnswer: Cease from man, for his breath is in his nostrils
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:22 urges to stop trusting in man because human life is fleeting and limited, paralleling Psalm 146:3 and Jeremiah 17:5 which warn against placing ultimate trust in humans rather than God.

questions.question: What does Isaiah 2:7 say about the land of the people in terms of wealth and military resources?
options: Their land is full of silver, gold, horses, and chariots
Their land is barren and poor
They have no horses or chariots
questions.correctAnswer: Their land is full of silver, gold, horses, and chariots
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:7 highlights the material wealth and military strength of the land, indicating reliance on earthly resources rather than God. This theme of misplaced trust is echoed in Psalm 20:7 and Jeremiah 9:23.

questions.question: According to Isaiah 2:9, what is the instruction regarding forgiving those who bow down and humble themselves?
questions.correctAnswer: Therefore forgive them not
questions.explanation: Isaiah 2:9 states not to forgive those who bow down and humble themselves hypocritically, highlighting God’s displeasure with insincere repentance. This aligns with Jesus’ teaching on true repentance in Matthew 7:21 and Psalm 78:36-37.
